ul.li: Thinking about accessibility
The personal nature of ability and disability
The experience of disability
Accessibility vs. Accommodation
Background in engineering and human factors.
Learned about accessibility through working on building devices and writing software at the Trace Center at University of Wisconsin-Madison
30 Years at the University of Illinois at Urbana/Champaign in Disability Services helping the university understand the accessibility barriers and solutions of the information age.

25+ years in participating in the development of accessibility standards at the W3C:
User Agent Accessibility Guidelines 1.0
Accessible Rich Internet Applications (WAI-ARIA)
ARIA Authoring Practices
ARIA and Assistive Technologies Community Group

Developing open-source (e.g. free) tools to support accessibility:
AInspector for WCAG Evaluation
Headings, Landmarks and Links (H2L)
SkipTo.js

fieldset.legend: What kind of work do you do?
Body Mass Index: Do you consider yoruself to be
Have you used tobacco products in the past year?
Lifestyle: How healthy is your lifestyle? Consider regular physical exams, regular exercise, stress, sleep and eating habits, drug or alcohol abuse.

Medical Conditions: Do you have or are you undergoing treatment for: diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, heart disease, cancer, chronic back or joint pain, drug, alcohol or food addiction, anxiety or depression?

contents.h2: 2010 U.S. Rates for Disability By Age

slide.title: Prevalence of Disability Among College Students

contents.h2: 2024 Prevalence of Disability Among College Students

slide.title: Types of Hearing Impairments in College Students

ul.li: Conductive Hearing Loss: This type occurs when something blocks or prevents sound from entering the outer or middle ear, such as earwax buildup, fluid from allergies, or ear infections.

Sensorineural Hearing Loss: This is the most common type and results from damage to the inner ear's structures or the auditory nerve. It can be caused by aging, noise exposure, certain diseases, or genetic factors.
Mixed Hearing Loss: This is a combination of both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.
Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD): This is a less common condition that affects the signals from the ear to the brain, even if the ear itself functions normally.
Noise-Induced Hearing Loss: Exposure to loud environments like concerts, music events, or heavy machinery can lead to hearing damage over time.
Medical Conditions: Infections, head injuries, and the use of certain medications (ototoxicity) can also contribute to hearing loss.
Congenital Conditions: Some students may have inherited conditions or issues with ear development from birth.
Difficulty with grammar, spelling, and vocabulary.
Challenges in taking notes during lectures and understanding spoken information.
Struggling to participate in class discussions and follow lectures.
Problems comprehending information from educational videos and presentations.
Social isolation in less interaction with peers and instructors.

Low vision: A severe visual impairment that cannot be corrected by standard eyeglasses, contact lenses, medication, or surgery. Students with low vision may use a combination of sight and other senses to learn, but they often require adaptations like magnified text or enhanced lighting.

Legal blindness: A designation defined by a visual acuity of 20/200 or less in the better eye after correction, or a visual field restricted to 20 degrees or less. While legally blind, many students still have some usable vision.
Total blindness: A complete lack of light perception, meaning the student must use alternative methods like Braille and auditory cues to access information.
Reading difficulties: Slower reading speed and lower comprehension due to eye strain and poor visual acuity.
Difficulty with visuals: Challenges understanding charts, diagrams, and other visual teaching aids.
Limited incidental learning: Less able to learn from visual observation of their environment.
Eye fatigue: Frequent headaches and fatigue that reduce stamina for studying.
Social isolation: May feel self-conscious or be excluded from activities, affecting their confidence.
Increased anxiety and stress: Frustration from academic challenges and a loss of independence can impact mental health.

Reading, Writing, and Math Difficulties: Specific learning disabilities like dyslexia (reading), dysgraphia (writing), and dyscalculia (math) can make grasping concepts and completing assignments difficult.
Information Processing and Memory: Students may struggle with processing information, recalling what has been taught, or interpreting complex charts and graphs.
Attention and Focus: Many students face difficulties maintaining attention, are easily distracted, and find it hard to juggle multiple tasks.
Time Management: Students often have trouble with planning, starting tasks, and meeting deadlines, leading to difficulty with time management.
Organization: Problems with overall organization are common, affecting written work and efficient use of library resources.
Stigma: A stigma surrounds learning disabilities, causing students to feel ashamed or isolated and reluctant to seek support.
Mental Health: Academic struggles can lead to feelings of defeatism, stress, and other psycho-social issues, increasing the risk of dropping out.
Social Skills: Inconsistent perceptual abilities can sometimes affect the interpretation of non-verbal cues like tone of voice, impacting social interactions.
Lack of Awareness/Training: Many faculty members receive insufficient training on accommodating students with learning disabilities, creating barriers to access.
Confusing Processes: Students often find the process of applying for accommodations confusing and stressful.
Lack of Self-Advocacy: Students, particularly those newly diagnosed, may lack the skills or awareness to effectively advocate for their needs.

img.alt: Image showing the percpetion of different types of color blindess

ul.li: Protanopia: No red cones.
Deuteranopia: No green cones.
Tritanopia: No blue cones.
Monochromacy: No color perception.

img.alt: Image showing what people see with different types of visual impairments

ul.li: Glaucoma: Peripheral vision loss.
Refractive Errors: Blurry vision.
Cataracts: Loss of contrast and visual field obstruction.
Diabetic Retinopathy: Visual field obstruction.
Macula Degeneration: Central vision loss, loss of color perception.

slide.title: Activity: Using a screen reader to navigate the web

ul.li: macOS: Voice Over (Built-in)
Windows: Narrator (Built-in)
Windows: JAWS (Most popular in US)
Windows: NVDA (open-source)
Unix/Linux: Orca (open-source)
Roles: What is the type of content or control and keyboard interaction.
Accessible Name: Purpose of this control or element (e.g. button, text box, ...).
Accessible Description: Instructions or error feedback in using a control.
Properties: Am I checked, is there an error, or is something open.

slide.title: Voice Over Screen Reader Concepts and Selected Commands

tr.td: Open rotor to navigate content on the web page and use the left or right arrow keys to show the list of headings.

ul.li: Voice Over allows you to navigate content .
When navigating a web page Voice Over announces heading information when the browse or focus cursor enters a new heading.

li.a: Penn State: Voice Over for OS X

slide.title: NVDA Screen Reader Concepts and Selected Commands

ul.li: Toggle between focus mode and browse mode.
Must be in browse mode for the following commands to work.

tr.td: Next heading at the corresponding level

ul.li: In browse mode you can move sequentially or by level through the headings on the page or view a list of links.
When navigating the content of a web page NVDA announces heading information is announced.

slide.title: JAWS Screen Reader Concepts and Selected Commands

ul.li: Toggle on/off virtual JAWS cursor for reading web pages.
Must be in virtual mode for the following commands to work.

tr.td: Next heading at the corresponding level

ul.li: In virtual you can move sequentially through the headings on a page or view a list of headings.
When navigating a web page JAWS announces heading information when the virtual or PC cursor is on a heading.

li.a: Penn State: JAWS commands for web
Freedom Scientific: JAWS commands for web

ul.li: macOS: Zoom (Built-in)
Windows: Magnifier (Built-in)
Windows: ZoomText
Windows or macOS: Read and Write
Windows or macOS: Kurzweil 3000

slide.title: Victor Tsaran (Yahoo/PayPal/Google) on the Technology and Disability

ul.li: Access to information is a human right, not just a nice thing to do.
Accessible at the same time as everyone else gets the information.

contents.p: The image shows two side-by-side images of three children watching a baseball game from the outfield fence. In the first image demonstrates equality since they all have a box to help them see over the fence. One child is tall enough to see over the fence standing on the box, the second child can only barely see over the fence standing on the box and the third child in a wheelchair cannot evvn get on the box. The second image shows the same children in equality with the features they need to see the game. The tallest child with one box has what they need, the second child now has two boxes and they no longer have to struggle to see the game. The child in the wheelchair has a ramp so they can now see the game unobstructed.

ul.li: Inaccessible experiences and materials exclude students.

Accommodations are modifications or adjustments made for an individual with a disability on an as-needed basis, and give access to whoever is there at the moment, which requires extra work on students, staff and faculty.
Accessible digital experiences and materials provide equal access for everyone without extra work.

p.a: Adapted from University of Minnesota: Accessibility vs. Accommodation

ul.li: Recruiting Interest
Sustaining Effort and Persistence
Self Regulation
Perception
Language and Symbols
Comprehension
Physical Action
Expression and Communication
Executive Functions

iframe.title: YouTube video player
iframe.allow: accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share

ul.li: Providing opportunities (e.g. Accessibility) instead of barriers (e.g. Accommodation) for people with disabilities
Everyone will have functional limitations (e.g. disability) as we age
Designing a better web for everyone, including ourselves
Universal Design in Learning helps everyone including people with disabilities!
